title.narrative: Burkina Faso: Appui a la bonne gouvernance (2008-2015)

description.narrative:
The program aims to strengthen Burkina Faso's government. The program has three components: ( 1) Support to the country's decentralization process ( 2 ) grants to promote and ensure greater respect for human rights, and ( 3 ) support for increasing equality between men and women.
Denmark supports via the program both civil society organizations and government institutions.
Contributions from various development partners are harmonized as far as possible through joint funding mechanisms and management committees.
The decentralization component provides support to promote local democracy and improve the administration of the tasks and resources which according to the country's decentralization plan must be transferred to the local level. The support to the government's decentralization plan is channeled via by the Ministry of Decentralization.
In the human rights component, support is provided to ensure Burkina Faso's residents a greater knowledge of and respect for their human rights. In addition to support for the Human Rights Ministry also a number of civil society organizations are supported, working for people's human rights to be respected, for guaranteeing media and freedom of speech and the promotion of public debate concerning elections, democracy and equality.
The gender component supports improvement of equality between men and women, focusing on the promotion of equality before the law, equal access to economic resources and equal access to political decision-making. The support is channeled through a joint fund for equality. The Joint Fund shall mainly support civil society organizations working for equality, but public institutions can also apply to the fund for funding for gender equality activities. The Ministry for Women receives direct support to the implementation of Burkina Faso's first national policy on equality. In addition, support is given to the fight against female genital mutilation, also through a joint fund.
